guide.introduction:
Get your shades on … these SMDs are bright!

Are you a beginner who wants to learn surface-mount soldering? This is the kit for you. Designed by young maker Joey Hudy, this kit is easy and straightforward to build. The LEDs are individually addressable, and everything is included except soldering tools and the Arduino. Your Joey #1 SMD Arduino Shield Kit can be built in less than 2 hours.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Get your shades on … these SMDs are bright!

Are you a beginner who wants to learn surface-mount soldering? This is the kit for you. Designed by young maker Joey Hudy, this kit is easy and straightforward to build. The LEDs are individually addressable, and everything is included except soldering tools and the Arduino. Your Joey #1 SMD Arduino Shield Kit can be built in less than 2 hours.

Relevant parts
  • Make: Joey #1 SMD Arduino Shield Kit
  • Arduino
  • Solder
  • Flux
Tools
  • Safety glasses
  • Soldering iron
  • Tweezers

lines.text: This technique locks your items in place for easier soldering:
lines.text_raw: '''This technique locks your items in place for easier soldering:'''

lines.text: If using flux, place flux on the spot you will be soldering.
lines.text_raw: If using flux, place flux on the spot you will be soldering.

lines.text: Place a dab of solder on one joint, as shown in the first image. (This is the way I do it … not necessarily the only way.)
lines.text_raw: Place a dab of solder on one joint, as shown in the first image. (This is the way I do it … not necessarily the only way.)

lines.text: Warm up your solder by placing your soldering iron on the dab of solder, as shown in the third image.
lines.text_raw: Warm up your solder by placing your soldering iron on the dab of solder, as shown in the third image.

lines.text: This will lock your piece in place. It makes it easier to solder the rest of the joints.

lines.text_raw: '''SMD LED configuration on the shield:'''

lines.text: VERY IMPORTANT: Notice in the first image that the SMD has a green line on the side.
lines.text_raw: VERY IMPORTANT: Notice in the first image that the SMD has a green line on the side.

lines.text: The green goes on the right (+) side on the PCB, as shown in the second image.

steps.title: Start your kit: Solder the SMD LEDs

lines.text: SMDs are tiny. Don't forget to use your tweezers — and maybe a magnifying glass!
lines.text_raw: SMDs are tiny. Don't forget to use your tweezers — and maybe a magnifying glass!

lines.text: Place your little dab of solder on the left pad, as shown in the first image. Really, you can use whichever side is easier for you. The idea is to lock it into place.
lines.text_raw: Place your little dab of solder on the left pad, as shown in the first image. Really, you can use whichever side is easier for you. The idea is to lock it into place.

lines.text: Place your SMD on the board, and heat up your solder. Remember this will help lock it into place.
lines.text_raw: Place your SMD on the board, and heat up your solder. Remember this will help lock it into place.

lines.text: Don't forget about the green line. It goes on the + side (right side).
lines.text_raw: Don't forget about the green line. It goes on the + side (right side).

lines.text: Solder the other end, as shown in the third image.
lines.text_raw: Solder the other end, as shown in the third image.

lines.text: Continue on to solder all 64 SMDs.
lines.text_raw: Continue on to solder all 64 SMDs.

lines.text: Note that the shift registers have to be put in the correct way:
lines.text_raw: Note that the shift registers have to be put in the correct way:

lines.text: There is a little circle on the shift register. Trust me, it's there!
lines.text_raw: There is a little circle on the shift register. Trust me, it's there!

lines.text: There is a notch on the PCB where the shift register should be placed, as shown in the first image.
lines.text_raw: There is a notch on the PCB where the shift register should be placed, as shown in the first image.

lines.text: The circle edge on the shift register should be on the same side as the notch — the left side.
lines.text_raw: The circle edge on the shift register should be on the same side as the notch — the left side.

lines.text: Solder using same technique as in Step 3.
lines.text_raw: Solder using same technique as in Step 3.

lines.text: Don't forget there are 2 shift registers!
lines.text_raw: Don't forget there are 2 shift registers!

lines.text: Solder the button in place as shown in the first image, using the same technique.
lines.text_raw: Solder the button in place as shown in the first image, using the same technique.

lines.text: Place each Arduino pin into the correct holes on your Arduino. The long ends go into the Arduino, as shown in the second image.
lines.text_raw: Place each Arduino pin into the correct holes on your Arduino. The long ends go into the Arduino, as shown in the second image.

lines.text: Place your PCB on top of the pins. You will see the very short pieces through the top, as shown in the third image.
lines.text_raw: Place your PCB on top of the pins. You will see the very short pieces through the top, as shown in the third image.

lines.text: Solder.
lines.text_raw: Solder.

lines.text: You've done it! You soldered an SMD shield for Arduino!
lines.text_raw: You've done it! You soldered an SMD shield for Arduino!

steps.title: Attach the shield to the Arduino

lines.text: Attach the shield to your Arduino. Line up all the pins with the headers and gently press it into place.
lines.text_raw: Attach the shield to your Arduino. Line up all the pins with the headers and gently press it into place.

lines.text: Connect your Arduino to your computer, and install the test code.
lines.text_raw: Connect your Arduino to your computer, and install the test code.

lines.text: Test code can be found here.
lines.text_raw: Test code can be found [https://github.com/Make-Magazine/SMD-Shield|here].

lines.text: Try more code — or make your own!
lines.text_raw: Try more code — or make your own!

lines.text: Remember all the SMD LEDs are individually addressable.
lines.text_raw: Remember all the SMD LEDs are individually addressable.

lines.text: Have fun!
lines.text_raw: '''Have fun!'''
